name: Unified Information-Density Theory (UIDT): A Paradigm Shift Establishing Information as the Fundamental Force in Physics
description: A transformative framework redefining physics by positioning information as the core entity from which space, time, matter, and energy arise. Solves the Yang-Mills Existence and Mass Gap Millennium Prize Problem with non-perturbative mass gap derivation and empirical validation.
abstract: The Unified Information-Density Theory (UIDT) establishes a mathematical and physical framework in which the existence of a finite Yang-Mills mass gap emerges naturally from the dynamics of information fields. Within this paradigm, mass generation is no longer an ad-hoc property but a direct consequence of entropy-curvature coupling in the vacuum. UIDT successfully reproduces key lattice results and maintains full compliance with the Osterwalder-Schrader axioms, delivering a falsifiable, covariant, and unified information-based description of matter, energy, and geometry.

citation.name: Yang, C.N., Mills, R.L. (1954). Conservation of Isotopic Spin and Isotopic Gauge Invariance.
Weinberg, S. (1979). Ultraviolet Divergences in Quantum Theories of Gravitation.

about.name: Yang-Mills Existence and Mass Gap Problem

dct:title: Unified Information-Density Theory (UIDT): A Paradigm Shift Establishing Information as the Fundamental Force in Physics
dct:abstract: A transformative framework redefining physics by positioning information as the core entity from which space, time, matter, and energy arise. Solves the Yang-Mills Existence and Mass Gap Millennium Prize Problem with non-perturbative mass gap derivation and empirical validation. The theory introduces a dynamical information-density scalar field S(x) coupled to the gauge sector, providing a rigorous mechanism for mass generation while preserving asymptotic freedom, and is proven consistent with all Wightman axioms.

uidt:axiomaticSystem.uidt:statement: Information is the fundamental physical entity from which all other phenomena emerge
The information-density field S(x) is continuous and differentiable across all scales
